questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. The code fetches the latest order from the purchases table for a specific user. An engineer needs to pass query parameters to the execute function to prevent an SQL injection attack. Which code snippet must be placed in the blank in the code to meet this requirement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is a parameterization method, better for SQL Injection; C is a ecaping method, better for XSS according to the DevCore study guide

Moreover C has a syntax error

Moreover ChatGPT sais B:
This code is using Python to execute a SQL query against a database using parameterized queries to prevent SQL injection attacks. Specifically, it is selecting the orders column from the purchases table where the username column matches the username variable. The username variable is passed in as a parameter in a dictionary format using the % operator to substitute the value into the query string. This approach is recommended for preventing SQL injection attacks because it ensures that user input is treated as data rather than as part of the SQL statement itself.

comments.content:
A clear explanation of all this answers and why B is correct
https://realpython.com/prevent-python-sql-injection/

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
the use of placeholder and key value will prevent inject SQL injection.

Selected Answer: B
Regarding to the MySQL Document, it presented following demo code:

select_stmt = "SELECT * FROM employees WHERE emp_no = %(emp_no)s"
cursor.execute(select_stmt, { 'emp_no': 2 })

Therefore, I choose the answer B as the correct one.

Selected Answer: D
This is getting discussed a lot so I took the Time to write some code and test this. Here is my code: https://gist.github.com/Ghiritaia/0e07dc4ed05763738298453927c05450. Answers A and D are the same and therefore correct. I'll go with D because is the cleaner code.

comments.content: Dude, C contains a dollar sign $s and not %s. It is wrong.

discussion.content:
I think the answer could be C, as the other answers do not do any escaping, only C does.

The following syntax is correct
>>> print(" what is '%s' " % ("hello".replace("","")))

Both A and D are the same answer.
They both work.
Depends on Python2 or python3
Yes, answer is A.

the given answer is correct. 
it can't be A. A is same as D.
https://www.w3schools.com/sql/sql_injection.asp

comments.content: Only f-strings do not work in Python 2.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Answer is A

choices.A:
cursor.execute("SELECT orders FROM purchases WHERE
username = '{}'".format (username))
choices.D:
cursor.execute (f"SELECT orders FROM purchases WHERE
username = '{username}'")
choices.B:
cursor.execute("SELECT orders FROM purchases WHERE
username = %(username)s", {'username': username})
choices.C:
cursor.execute("SELECT orders FROM purchases WHERE
username = '$s' % username".replace("'", "''"))

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

Drag and drop the code from the bottom onto the box where the code is missing in the Ansible script to get the existing firewall rules from Cisco Meraki and store the results to a new variable. Not all options are used.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
delegate_to
register: rules
rules.data

The answer was in this page: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/scenario_guides/guide_meraki.html

This is a result:

- name: Get firewall rules
 meraki_mx_l3_firewall:
 auth_key: KEY123
 org_name: example_org
 net_name: example_net
 state: query
 delegate_to: localhost
 register: rules
- set_fact:
 original_ruleset: '{{rules.data}}'

delegate_to: localhost
 register: rules
- set_fact:
 original_ruleset: '{{rules.data}}'

choices.B: simplifies the development of clients by using a single encoding standard for the data
choices.D: enables the application to pull data faster than pushing the data
choices.A: reduces the load on the server by enabling the client to pull data
choices.C: enables operational data to be collected at higher rates and a higher scale

questions.question_text: What is a benefit of using model-driven telemetry?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct.
D isnâ€™t coz MDT is based on a push model rather than pull, so this option is incorrect.

In MDT there is only push method, from server(device/publisher) to subscriber, with 2 types of sessions: dial-in (dynamic, where subscriber use NETCONF to ask for data) and dial0out(gRPC, configured from CLI)
 IMO, the answer is C

Selected Answer: C
correct answer should be C.

Selected Answer: A
Model-driven telemetry is a telemetry collection method that uses pre-defined models to represent the data being collected. This makes it easier to develop clients that can read and understand the data, and it also allows for more efficient data collection.

One of the benefits of using model-driven telemetry is that it reduces the load on the server by enabling the client to pull data. This is because the client only needs to request the data that it needs, rather than receiving all of the data that is being collected. This can improve performance and scalability, especially for applications that are collecting a lot of data.

So the answer is (A).

Selected Answer: C
I asked ChatGPT and it answered C.
How confident are you in your answer?
I am highly confident in my answer, Model-driven telemetry is a feature that allows devices to collect operational data at a high rate and scale. This is achieved by using a standard data model, which defines the data that should be collected, and a standard encoding format, which defines how the data should be encoded and sent to the collector. The standard data model and encoding format allow devices to send data in a consistent format, which makes it easier to process and analyze the data.
correct answer should be C.
